lessonTitle: The Boundary as Ontological Act: From Distinction to Civilization

questions.question: According to the lesson, what are the three irreducible poles of reality created by the act of abstraction?
questions.correct_answer: The Observed (that which finds itself on this side of the boundary), The Observer (the one for whom this distinction is drawn), and The Non-observed or Nothing (the fundamental background from which the boundary is drawn).

questions.question: What is the starting point before the act of abstraction occurs?
questions.correct_answer: A pre-reflective state of undifferentiated Being - not chaos, but wholeness where there is neither subject nor object, nor 'something.'

questions.question: What are the two possible modes of relating to another Observer's boundary?
questions.correct_answer: Ignoring his boundary (which leads to violence and appropriation) or recognizing his boundary (which is the beginning of cooperation and exchange).

questions.question: Name three of the six quantum levels of civilization mentioned in the lesson.
questions.correct_answer: Any three of: Family, Kinship/Clan, Tribe, Nation, Religion, Civil Society.

questions.question: According to the lesson, what is the main threat to civilization?
questions.correct_answer: Ontological regression, when complex, universal, legal boundaries are replaced by primitive, particular, violent ones based on blood, faith, or passport, or when systemic violence is masked as technical necessity.
